Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Kinetic sieving; Size exclusion; Hindered diffusion

Other Information.Additional Info: Hysteretic desorption observed. Adsorption kinetics are very slow (ca. 50 h for a cycle) due to hindered diffusion through ultramicropores of comparable size. High H2 loading at low pressures might impede flexibility and window-opening, leading to slow desorption.
Not adsorbed at 77 K due to size exclusion.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Guest-induced framework flexibility and pore expansion; Cooperative adsorption

Other Information.Additional Info: Readily incorporated despite being slightly larger than the pore size. Uptake occurs through a transient phase and channels expansion. Strong host-guest interaction (adsorption heat 49-55 kJ mol-1). Flexibility of the porous framework at higher temperatures enables diffusion.

Sieving Mechanism: Molecular sieving based on rigid pore apertures at low temperature (H2/N2); Guest-induced framework flexibility and pore expansion for larger molecules (CO2) at higher temperatures.

Experimental Validation.Method: Adsorption isotherms; Variable-temperature X-ray powder diffraction (TXRPD); Thermogravimetry (TG); Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC); CO2 isobar measurement
Experimental Validation.Performance Metrics: H2 uptake: 0.56 wt% and 0.010 kg H2/L at 90 K and 900 Torr (density: 0.023 molecules Å-3); CO2 uptake: 7.6 wt% at 273 K and 900 Torr (density: 0.014 molecules Å-3); Selective H2 over N2 adsorption.

Other Information.Additional Info: Thermally activated form of [Cu(F-pymo)2(H2O)1.25]n (1). Flexible porous network that undergoes guest-induced structural modification, affecting its magnetic properties (increase in weak ferromagnetic ordering transition temperature from 22 K to 29 K upon CO2 incorporation). Ultramicropore-filling leads to very high guest densities.
